keyTakeAways: More than half of the 92 teams in England and Wales' top four leagues have American ownership, with investments also occurring in Scotland and across Europe.
American investors find British soccer more affordable compared to U.S. sports franchises like NFL and NBA, where teams cost $6–8 billion.
U.S. celebrities such as Will Ferrell, Snoop Dogg, LeBron James, Tom Brady, and Ryan Reynolds are investing in British clubs, bringing celebrity visibility and commercial benefits.
The success of the TV show 'Ted Lasso' has significantly boosted American interest in British soccer, portraying an American coach managing a London team.
American ownership has led to increased investment in women's football and commercial growth, including better stadium infrastructure and player recruitment.
American fans and supporters in the U.K. generally welcome the investments, despite concerns about potential changes to the league structure or gameplay.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing trend of American investment in British soccer is transforming the ownership landscape of English and Welsh football. Over half of the top-tier teams now have some form of American ownership, with celebrities like Will Ferrell, LeBron James, and Tom Brady investing in clubs such as Leeds, Liverpool, and Birmingham. American investors are attracted by the affordability of British teams compared to U.S. franchises, and are making strategic investments in both elite and lower-tier clubs. Celebrity involvement, especially through documentaries like 'Welcome to Wrexham' and the TV show 'Ted Lasso,' has significantly raised American awareness and interest in British soccer. This investment has also led to commercial growth and increased investment in women's football. While some fans in the U.K. express concern about potential changes to the game, most welcome the modernization and development of their teams, citing improved facilities and better player recruitment. As American fans grow in number—driven by the pandemic and upcoming global events like the 2026 World Cup—the trend is expected to continue and expand.
title: Why are so many rich Americans investing in British soccer teams?
